data.title: Surface Pro and TouchScreenButton do not work
data.body:
Hi there,

I found that the Surface Pro's touch screen is not detected by Godot, even when using Emulate Touch Screen in the prefs.  TouchScreenButtons do not seem to receive touches.

On Windows 8, if emulate touch screen is active and you're on a system where multitouch is supported, it'd be nice for Godot to switch and allow the touch screen buttons to work correctly.  However, if emulate touch screen is off, Windows 8 should react as would a regular desktop system.

As an aside, it would also be nice if Surface Pro swipes, pinches, and two-finger pans worked in the editor.  Swiping would scroll lists (which it tries to do currently, but when you release it changes the selected item; scrolling in the code editor with a finger does not work and would be preferable to trying to select), two-fingers would pan viewports, and pinches could be used for zooms.  Perhaps a double-tap with a finger in the game viewport could also return to default zoom.

Thanks!

data.title: support backslash (\) for multiline in gdscript
BUG - "Godot quit unexpectedly" - Mac OSX 10.8.5
data.body:
Overview:
After the first time I closed down Godot, it instantly crashes every time I attempt to reopen it, throwing up the typical Mac error message "Godot quit unexpectedly".

Problem (steps):
1. I extracted Godot from the ZIP file downloaded from the website.
2. I placed the Godot application in my Applications directory.
3. I launched Godot and it opened perfectly fine, as expected.
4. I closed Godot.
5. I reopened Godot and was given the error "Godot quit unexpectedly".
6. I attempted to select "Reopen" on the error message window and continued to get the same error message and was unable to open Godot.

Attempted Solutions:
1. I moved the Godot application to my trash bin and emptied my trash.
2. I re-extracted the application from the original ZIP file.
3. I moved the application to my Application directory (same location as first attempt).
4. I reopened the Godot application and the application opened without any issues.
5. I closed the application again.
6. I reopened the application and got the same error message as before, and was unable to open Godot.
7. I repeated the earlier steps and it works just the same. The first time I open the application, it works just fine, but as soon as I attempt to reopen the application after closing it, it fails.

My computer specs:
Apple iMac (2007)
Mac OS X 10.8.5
Processor 2.8 GHz Intel Core 2 Duo
Memory 4 GB 667 MHz DDR2 SDRAM

Label:
Bug

data.title: The theme editor sucks in general.
data.body:
Reduz's words, not mine. :V From the thread where I originally brought this up in the forums:

"I know that creating GUI themes that let you change default fonts and colors requires creation of a Theme resource. Some sort of special editor displaying all the widgets does come up. But it's not at all obvious what to do with it. I can click on the Theme menu and get some sort of Add dialog for specific parts of specific elements.

So let's say I want to change the entire GUI in my application to use a certain font. Everything should use this font. But it seems like you can only theme things on a per-class basis. So I decided, okay, let's start with the label. I add the label, it gives me the style options I'm used to. I set the font... and nothing happens. The label in the view looks exactly the same. I later discover you have to navigate away from the theme and go back for the change to appear. That's not good.

Okay... well, what I was really interested in is changing the fonts on buttons since that's impossible to do in the regular gui building view. So I add every item for the button class. ...there is no way to change the font. What?! That's exactly like the regular gui building view!

Not only that, but it does not seem that there is any way to apply this theme in the gui editor. It can be done programmatically using Control.set_theme... but that's no good because then you're basically going blind at that point; you don't know what your gui will look like with the theme until you run it.

So how exactly am I supposed to set the font, or heck, _anything_, on a gui-wide basis and design around it?"

data.title: Create docs for engine hackers
data.body:
Hey everyone,

I've started hacking on the engine (because I'm stuck at home with a bad cold), and for starters I began converting the code to c++11 (https://github.com/Ed-von-Schleck/godot/tree/c++11). Don't expect anything big soon, though. Skimming through the code there a lot of questions piling up in the vain of: Why re-invent the standard library (I started to tackle that, as you can see)? Why so much code duplication (and is there a goal to properly factor out copy&pasted code)? Why so little comments? Is there a possibility that the documentation system (I haven't really spent time with it) might be converted to something more standard (e.g. doxygen)? What's with the slightly odd coding style? What's with the tests (e.g. 'bin/godot -test gui' just opens a window, but I don't see automated tests running)? Where's the git (or whatever you used previously) history?

The forum seems to aim primarily at game devs, and not so much engine hackers. That's fine, but it leaves the impression that the engine is still something of an in-house, throw-over-the-wall-kind-of project.

I'd _love_ to see documentation outlining answers to these kinds of questions (and more) and guidelines for hacking the engine. Also, I think a mailing list would be great.

Thanks for the open-sourcing of the engine! I believe it opens up great possibilities to improve the code quality of the engine.

data.title: wiki doesn't has enough information about extending engine code
data.body:
Please update wiki about advanced topics like:
- what is general architecture of engine?
- how to start writing c++ extension?
- what is the export template from developer perspective and how it possible to 
  tune template code or write new from scratch?
- what is development environment you would like to recommend to working on engine code?

In other words please also provide documentation for quick starting contribution for engine itself.

data.title: Running godot on Linux via bumblebee is broken
data.body:
For those who don't know what optirun is, it is a program on linux that allows you to run other programs on an alternate graphics card (Namely on nVidia Optimus systems).

This is very important for those of us with somewhat older laptops (mine is a 2010), due to the fact that the Intel cards have a tendency to render faces on the wrong side of an object.  Using optirun, we can run the program with a better GPU, eliminating those glitches.

Results of running `optirun ./godot_x11.64` and attempting to edit a project:

```
opening pack (CURRENT WORKING DIR)/godot_x11.64, -1, -1
opening pack (CURRENT WORKING DIR)/data.pck, -1, -1
opening pack (CURRENT WORKING DIR)/data.pcz, -1, 0
opening pack (CURRENT WORKING DIR)../data.pck, -1, -1
opening pack (CURRENT WORKING DIR)../data.pcz, -1, 0
opening pack (CURRENT WORKING DIR)../..data.pck, -1, -1
opening pack (CURRENT WORKING DIR)../..data.pcz, -1, 0
opening pack (CURRENT WORKING DIR)../../../data.pck, -1, -1
opening pack (CURRENT WORKING DIR)../../../data.pcz, -1, 0
opening pack //data.pck, -1, -1
opening pack //data.pcz, -1, 0
ERROR: set_custom_property_info: Condition ' !props.has(p_prop) ' is true.
   At: core/globals.cpp:1317.
***** SET ICON ***** 128  128
ERROR: set_font: Condition ' p_font.is_null() ' is true.
   At: scene/resources/theme.cpp:302.
ERROR: set_stylebox: Condition ' p_style.is_null() ' is true.
   At: scene/resources/theme.cpp:251.
editor: 0
list diring on: (CURRENT WORKING DIR)../../../godot/plugins
ERROR: _load_recent_projects: Condition ' err!=OK ' is true. Continuing..:
   At: tools/editor/project_manager.cpp:393.
ERROR: _load_recent_projects: Condition ' err!=OK ' is true. Continuing..:
   At: tools/editor/project_manager.cpp:393.
ERROR: _load_recent_projects: Condition ' err!=OK ' is true. Continuing..:
   At: tools/editor/project_manager.cpp:393.
ERROR: _load_recent_projects: Condition ' err!=OK ' is true. Continuing..:
   At: tools/editor/project_manager.cpp:393.
OPENING: (CURRENT WORKING DIR)/TestProj (::CWD::TestProj)
ERROR: cleanup: ObjectDB Instances still exist!
   At: core/object.cpp:1656.
ERROR: set_custom_property_info: Condition ' !props.has(p_prop) ' is true.
   At: core/globals.cpp:1317.
~/$ CREATING RENDER THREAD
XIO:  fatal IO error 2 (No such file or directory) on X server ":8"
      after 41 requests (41 known processed) with 0 events remaining.
```

The project selector comes up, and running the projects runs them on the correct graphics card (without rendering glitches), but the edit button causes the crash mentioned above.  The same crash occurs if you optirun an exported project. (Linux 64-bit)

I'm not sure what causes this or how to fix it, as I've never had a problem with programs on optirun until now. (Sorry, I can't compile godot, I do not have administrator rights to my machine and therefore have a hard time installing deps)
